citation.article-title: Wolinella curva sp. nov.: "Vibrio succinogenes" of human origin.

p.s: Description of Wolinella curva sp. nov.
Wolinella curva (curv'a. L. adj. curva curved, bent, arched)
Cells are curved rods 0.5 to 1 μm wide by 2 to 6 μm long and have rounded or tapered ends.
Helical or straight cells may also exist.
Gram negative.
Rapid, darting motility.
Endospores are not produced.
Cell morphology as determined by electron microscopy.
In 2-day-old agar or broth cultures, cells of most strains appear as short, slightly curved rods with single polar flagella.
Cells with single flagella are observed less frequently among cells of the type strain than among cells of other strains of this species.
Cell length ranges from 0.65 to 4.75 μm, with mean lengths of 1.20 to 1.85 μm.
Strain VPI 10659 exhibits greater variability in cell length, with a range of 1.20 to 28.30 μm and a mean of 3.75 μm (Table 4 and Fig. 1 through 8).
Cell diameters of all strains range from 0.25 to 0.45 μm, with means of 0.35 to 0.40 μm.
In negatively stained preparations and in ultrathin sections, the cell surface has a convoluted contour that is typical of most gram-negative bacteria (Fig. 5 through 8).
In sections, a distinct nucleoid region is present in all cells.
Polar caps similar to the structures described by Ritchie et al. (15) and Lai et al. (9) are present in all of the strains which we examined (Fig. 7 and 8).
Cytoplasmic inclusions are rare; they appear as circular electron-dense bodies that are generally 0.05 μm or less in diameter (Fig. 5).
The outer layers of the cells consist of a highly convoluted outer membrane with a less distinct inner or cytoplasmic membrane.
These layers are separated by an electron-lucent space of irregular width.
A distinct, electron-dense peptidoglycan layer between the inner and outer membranes cannot readily be identified (Fig. 6).
The description given above applies equally to all strains of W. curva, to W. succinogenes (strains ATCC 29543T and Y-IB4), and to unrelated strain VPI 10279.
Morphological characteristics are of limited value in distinguishing among these species.
In contrast, W. recta exhibits a distinctive cell wall structure in which the outer membrane is covered with a distinctive array of hexagonally packed macromolecular subunits (9).
Colonial morphology.
Translucent colonies are produced on blood agar plates.

The following three colony types occur: 1-mm-diameter, convex colonies, which are found with agar-pitting or -corroding colonies up to 5 mm in diameter or with spreading colonies up to 5 mm in diameter.
Agar-corroding or spreading colonies appear to be medium dependent, as only one of these variants occurs at a time.
Growth requirements.
Strains grow on agar surfaces in anaerobic and microaerophilic (5% oxygen) atmospheres containing H2.

There is no growth on agar surfaces in air enriched with 10% CO2, but strains grow when they are incubated in air in the freshly prepared broth medium described by Kafkewitz (7), which contains thioglycolate as a reducing agent.
All cultures require formate and fumarate for broth culture.
Strains grow less well in broth media supplemented with formate and nitrate (0.2%), but do not grow in broth media supplemented only with nitrate.
Hydrogen and formate are used as energy sources.
Formate is oxidized.
Hydrogen and carbon dioxide are produced in headspace gas over broth cultures (PPLO-FF medium).
Hydrogen is also detected in the headspace gas of W. succinogenes cultures.
This contrasts with a previous report (20), in which no hydrogen was detected with this species.
Fumarate is reduced to succinate.
Carbohydrates are not fermented and are not required for growth.
Biochemical characteristics and sensitivities to inhibitory agents.
The biochemical characteristics are shown in Tables 2 and 5 . Wolinella strains are oxidase positive, as determined with the reagent described by Tarrand and Groschel (22).

This finding contrasts with the results of the test performed with aqueous N, N,N',N'-tetramethyl-p-phenylene diamine dihydrochloride (3), but is consistent with the description of oxidase-positive oral Vibrio succinogenes-like organisms (23) and the presence of cytochromes in W. succinogenes and its ability to use low levels of oxygen (24).
Antibiotic susceptibilities.

Minimal inhibitory concentrations of antibiotics for W. curva (in micrograms per milliliter): bacitracin, >128; chloramphenicol, 2 to 4; clindamycin, 0.5 to 1; colistin, 4; erythromycin, 2; gentamicin, 2; kanamycin, 4 to 8; metronidazole, 1 to 2; minocycline, 2 to 4; nalidixic acid, 64 to 128; neomycin, 4 to 8; penicillin, 32; polymixin B, 8; rifampin, 128 to >128; streptomycin, 2; tetracycline, 1; vancomycin, >128 (21; this study).
DNA-DNA homologies. W. curva isolates have G+C contents of 43 to 47 mol% (Table 2).
Strains of W. curva form a distinct group with an intergroup homology of 80 to 100% (Table 3).
The W. curva isolates show no significant DNA homology with the type strain of W. succinogenes, the type strain of W. recta, or strain VPI 10279.
Serology.
None of the antisera against Wolinella strains react with the cells of other species of oral and nonoral microorganisms (Table 6).
The serological relationships among Wolinella species are shown in Table 7.
These reactions are consistent with the findings of Badger and Tanner (2), who used an agglutination assay.
However, the ELISA has the advantage of a distinct end result with the formation of a blue color.
After the specific antiglobulin has been made, prepared, and characterized, this assay can be performed faster than multiple biochemical tests.
As used in these studies, the ELISA does not require broth culture of test strains.
The G+C content of the DNA is 43 to 47 mol% (melting temperature method).
Strains were isolated from lesions in human oral cavities and from a blood culture.
Pathogenicity unknown.
The type strain is strain ATCC 35224 (= VPI 9584).
